content.html: Yeah, switching to static method or depending on your framework primitive container binding would allow you to use CarbonInterval. For me it's always a check of interests and how hard it's really to read and how often do I have. A cache TTL of 5min isn't really useful as carbon.
content.text:
Yeah, switching to static method or depending on your framework primitive container binding would allow you to use CarbonInterval.
For me it's always a check of interests and how hard it's really to read and how often do I have.
A cache TTL of 5min isn't really useful as carbon.

content.html: Yeah, I usually clarify with a comment. A static method that returns CarbonInterval::totalSeconds could work similarly to your original suggestion. Perhaps I'll give that a try!
content.text: Yeah, I usually clarify with a comment. A static method that returns CarbonInterval::totalSeconds could work similarly to your original suggestion. Perhaps I'll give that a try!

content.html: But how would you solve this when using constants?
content.text: But how would you solve this when using constants?

content.html: There isn't a solution. If you HAVE TO use constants I would recommend the single integer or multiplication with a comment that clarifies the unit and in best case also what the number means "5 days in seconds" or similar.
content.text: There isn't a solution. If you HAVE TO use constants I would recommend the single integer or multiplication with a comment that clarifies the unit and in best case also what the number means "5 days in seconds" or similar.
